txt: Many Canadians don’t vote because they feel a sense of apathy towards their government and politics in general.
It’s important to increase voter education.
It is important to support increased youth participation in politics.
Voting is too hard for people with disabilities.
I prefer to vote based on my principles, rather than try to vote strategically to minimize downside effects of my vote.
I always vote.
I think mandatory voting should be implemented.
I think there should be incentives for voting.
I think there should be a voting holiday.
I always feel like my vote is important.
My vote is wasted under the current electoral system and so I often choose not to vote.
We need better educational systems in place to inform voters on important issues.
It’s important that the Canadian government collect and assess the political opinions of Canadians in an open and transparent manner before making important decisions.
I am pleased with the current electoral system.
Our current electoral system has served Canadians well for decades and is efficient.
The current electoral system results in more stable governance (ie: more majority governments which can serve a full term).
If we used a system with proportional representation, the opinions would be too strongly divided and nothing would ever get done.
Electoral reform is a divisive issue and I don’t think a referendum is required in order to better gauge the true opinions of Canadians.
I wouldn’t trust online voting systems and would prefer to cast my ballot in person.
The government needs to engage in more discussions with all citizens.
I would like to vote for a non-partisan MP, but feel like my vote would be wasted.
I believe a party’s share of seats in the House of Commons should reflect its share of the popular vote.
The current electoral system does not represent voter preferences accurately and should be changed.
I would like Canada to implement an online voting system.
It is important to achieve broad support of all Canadians before moving forward with procedures for electoral reform.
The voting process is intimidating. I don’t even understand why I would vote for different candidates.
I am worried about security issues with online voting.
The current electoral system strengthens the dominance of the two major political parties, the Conservative Party and the Liberal Party.
The allocation of seats in the House of Commons should better reflect the popular vote.
The current electoral system leads to increased voter apathy and poor participation.
For online voting, I think we should base our decisions & timelines on the professional opinions of those in the digital security community.
I think we can and should come up with a cheaper and better way to run referendum-like national gut-checks.
I think my vote is wasted under the current electoral system.
I would like a system reflecting the percentage of votes and the views of groups too small to gain a voice.
Something like 30 seats in Parliament allocated on the basis of % of votes and another 10 allocated to the North and Aboriginals.
I would then roll back the growth in the number of ridings so that in total we have no more seats in total in Parliament than currently.
I think a system involving proportional representation for perhaps 10% of parliamentary seats could be an improvement.
I think a healthy system could involve giving groups too small to gain a voice (for example, Northern and Aboriginal communities), more seats than their small proportion.
I can explain the way our current electoral system works to a five year old.
I have a good understanding of alternative electoral systems.
The voting age should be lowered to 16.
Proportional representation ensures support of government policies by the broadest segment of Canadians- at the very least, a true majority
Proportional representation will reduce hyper-partisanship and promote greater collaboration and cooperation between parties.
Proportional representation will reduce wild policy swings and result in more long-lasting policies with a view to the future.
Governments are not accountable when most votes cast elect no-one and there are so many "safe" ridings under our current FPTP system
Proportional voting systems can be designed to provide both local representation and a Parliament that reflects Canadian diversity.
In general, the more proportional the system, the lower the income inequality; the more majoritarian the system, the higher the inequality.
Most countries which use proportional representation systems include a threshold a party must meet before it is entitled to any seats.
Given how over budget Phoenix Pay is, as one example, the federal government probably isn't ready to correctly implement online voting.
The more seats that a party has in Parliament, the greater its influence on government policy developed within a coalition government.
All citizens deserve equal and effective votes.
Winner-take-all systems (such as FPTP)reward regional parties, whose support is concentrated within a geographical area, with extra seats.
Fairness should be a high priority in any voting system.
Winner-take-all voting systems (such as FPTP) encourage "dog-whistle" politics and pandering to swing voters with short-sighted policies.
Ranked ballots provide real choices for voters if they are used in a proportional voting system.
Ranked ballots added to a winner-take-all voting system reduce vote-splitting to allow the largest parties to win more majority governments.
I'd rather have a MP in multi-member proportional riding that I voted for than a MP in a single-member riding that I did not vote for.
MPs in multi-member proportional ridings are more accountable to constituents because they face greater competition to be elected.
At present, no online voting system is immune to hacking, and therefore, is too risky for elections that matter.
Both Conservative voters in the Atlantic and Liberal voters in the West deserve greater representation in Parliament.
There should not be a huge variance in the number of votes that each party needs to secure a seat in Parliament. All votes should be equal.
A single MP cannot represent the government policy concerns of every constituent in his or her riding.
Parties should be a tool to help MPs be effective representatives of their constituents but often see MPs only as their representatives.
Policies are neither efficient nor effective if they are not supported by most Canadians over the long-term.
FPTP may seem like a simple voting system but most Canadians cannot figure out how to elect a MP of their own choosing.
Voters want to be able to choose parties that offer distinct choices.  Under FPTP, apparent differences are too often only cosmetic.
Big tent parties may have a diverse membership but all policy-making is filtered to achieve party goals.
Negotiations between parties to achieve a coalition government are more transparent than those between various factions in big tent parties.
Innovative ideas or proposals often seem radical or extreme until adopted by the mainstream.
Minority rights must be protected by Parliament.
I think we need to develop a proper national "digital identity system" before we can consider implementing online voting.
I understand how mixed-member proportional representation works.
I understand how single transferable vote (STV) works.
I want a fairer system than FPTP but not one in which MPs are appointed from a party list not selected by the public.
I find it confuses the conversation when people misuse "ranked ballots" as a euphemism for "instant runoff voting"
It's unacceptable to compromise on either the secret ballot or the verifiability of elections even if it would making voting more convenient
The party I most recently voted for federally would benefit from the reform I would like to see
I live in an urban (not a rural) area
Ballots should just show the candidates' names, not their parties, like they used to
The party I most recently supported federally would benefit from the reform I would like to see.
'Representative democracies' without PR often don't have real democracy, as parties can take complete control with a minority of the vote
Mandatory voting requirements will reduce the incentive for parties to  pander to extremist values
It should always be clear which party is accountable for decisions made by government, even if this means decisions are only made by 1 party
There should be parties in Parliament that represent the views of all Canadians, even if some are radical or extreme.
Even these questions are too vague to answer.
Many of these questions are too vague to answer.
Many of the comments here are too vague to answer.
Many of the comments here are difficult to vote on.
I think many of the comments here are difficult to vote on.
I am eligible to vote in Canada.
I think that a good consultation tool, be it digital or in-person, should allow participants (not just moderators) to shape conversation.
I think that a good consultation tool/process, be it digital or in-person, should allow participants (not just moderators) to shape conversation.
Our current electoral voting system can be improved in a way that can better represent Canada's diversity of opinions.
I think we should consider Score/Approval voting systems (also known as "range voting" systems).
Electoral reform should be decided by a randomly selected citizens assembly.
All parties have self-interest biases.
A Citizens' assembly is a good way to represent the whole electorate.
I think a "citizens' assembly" is a good way to represent the whole electorate.
I think all parties have self-interest biases.
I think electoral reform should be decided by a randomly selected citizens' assembly.
Region-specific issues and perspectives would be obscured by larger districts.
I want to be able to vote against candidates I disagree with.
It's important to me to deal with an MP from a national party that I support on local and personal issues.
I like to educate myself on my local candidates.
Sometimes I disagree with a candidate or party so much that I will vote for anyone else.
I am more concerned with my province's interests than my specific district's.
I have the time and interest to research many candidates.
I usually just vote based on party.
I often educate myself on my local candidates.
I believe our current electoral system has helped making our democracy one of the most stable in the world.
Political education is an important element in schooling
Schools need to teach more critical thought, so citizens may more closely examine political platforms/arguments & hold officials to account
I consider myself a person with a disability.
I consider myself as a person with a disability.
I am more concerned with federal-level issues than with issues of my particular riding.
I am more interested by an individual's beliefs than by their identity.
I understand what the Gallagher Index does.
I can explain specifically how the Gallagher Index works.
If given the choice, I would vote sincerely. But under our current system, I feel compelled to vote strategically.
I would like ballots to be more expressive than "select one candidate".
I have read the entirety of the report of the Special committee on Electoral Reform.
I watch parliament's question period regularly.
I have written to one or many members of parliament regarding my opinions on electoral reform.
Maintaining the anonymity of the secret ballot is more important to me than the convenience of voting online.
I am under 40 years old.
Those who support underrepresented parties are more likely to support electoral reform.
Those who support overrepresented parties are more likely to oppose electoral reform.
Under a system of proportional representation, parties have less to gain by engaging in voter suppression of their political opponents.
A party that receives less than 50% of the vote does not have a mandate to form a majority government.
I think Canada would be worse off if we had only two parties.
If Canada reforms it's electoral system, it should be to one less susceptible to strategic voting.
Between 2011 and 2015, I felt that the Liberal's underrepresentation in parliament was unfair.
I feel that politically similar parties should have to merge in order to gain a more proportional percentage of seats.
First-past-the-post encourages strategic voting.
There is less incentive to vote strategically in proportional systems.
Strategic voting results in people voting between the two most popular candidates.
Politically similar parties are pressured to merge by FPTP to gain proportional seats, such as the Conservative merger in 2003.
I support a form of Proportional Representation or Mixed Member Proportional as an option for a new electoral system.
I feel the current electoral system is undemocratic and biased.
I want my vote to count, because it doesn't now.
I would like to vote for independent candidates if it was an option.
I would like more choices of parties when it come to my vote
I am concerned that parties are  incentivized to advocate for electoral reforms that are self-serving.
If given the choice between an electoral system with only two parties or one that's proportional, I would prefer a proportional system.
I can explain what Duverger's Law is.
I would not want my preferred party to have disproportionate power.
A dictatorship, where only one vote counts, is an example of a disproportionate government.
A dictatorship is arguably the least proportionate system possible.
I do not want my preferred party to have greater-than-proportional representation in parliament.
I have voted knowing that the candidate for which I voted would win neither the most nor the second most votes.
Outside of governmental elections, I have made use of alternate electoral methods.
I have moved and therefore voted in more than one riding in the past 10 years.
I have voted for a third-party candidate in a federal election.
The Conservative merger of 2003 was good for the party, but reduced the number of parties in Canada, decreasing our party diversity.
I identify as female.
Election Day should be a civic holiday.
I think the government should demonstrate how different systems work based on last election results.
I feel that luring people in with the promise of engagement, and then sneakily trying to educate them, seems like a dirty tactic.
The Liberal party supported electoral reform in 2015 because they had 19% of the vote, but only 11% of the seats.
The Liberal party no longer supports meaningful electoral reform because they now have 55% of the seats with only 40% of the vote.
An electoral system can represent geographies, ideologies, and identities, but prioritizing one of these comes at a cost to the other two.
MMP is simpler to explain than STV.
STV's advantage over MMP is that it doesn't explicitly enshrine political parties in our electoral system.
MMP has a better chance of obtaining public support than STV due to its relative simplicity.
I can explain a Condorcet voting system.
I can explain an Approval voting system.
Despite Maryam Monsef's claim, I do not feel "empowered" by mydemocracy.ca.
Instant Runoff Voting is criticized as "complicated," but is actually simpler than the strategic voting needed to vote effectively in FPTP
I like the simplicity of stating my favourite candidate, and who I hope will win if my first choice does not receive enough votes.
I want a voting system that reduces negative campaigning.
Negative campaigning makes me so disgusted with all the candidates I don't really want to vote for any of them.
Universal suffrage (voting rights for all regardless of ethnicity or gender) is a good idea.
Defining the boundaries of electoral districts is best done by an independent body to reduce the likelihood of Gerrymandering.
I can explain Arrow's Impossibility Theorem.
People should only vote if they are well informed
Test
Parties are not necessary.
